title: a Homely, honest , reliable,
content:
Hello,

This is my first post on here!

I wondered if you knew of a typeface that represented these sort of values of a person:

honest, approachable, reliable, the original 'Mc'coy', and homely

I wondered if a serif typeface said 'stern' too much, so maybe a Sans Serif is more appropriate

By 'Original' I mean someone that has been about for years but is still among the best but maybe needing to be more modern
author: MrKerner

comments.content:
That's what slabs are for. And if you want a less stern one, the serifs should be slanted. Here's something you might like that I was fortunate to be involved in:  
 [http://ernestinefont.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/ernestinefont.com/ "http://ernestinefont.com/")

hhp

thankyou, slabs looks like a very good suggestion!

Do you know of any British Slab typefaces with a British history for example?

I can only think of Joanna, but it's pretty archaic-looking.

hhp

A British slab: [FS Clerkenwell](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/www.fontsmith.com/fonts/fs-clerkenwell.cfm). And less British: [FS Rufus](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/www.fontsmith.com/fonts/fs-rufus.cfm) (Did this one inspire Ernestine? It’s a bit similar, but less quirky.).

It's possible Rufus was inspired from the same thing Ernestine was inspired from - an old German face called Industria (not _that_ Industria) which can be seen here:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/50670](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/typophile.com/node/50670 "http://typophile.com/node/50670")

hhp
Interesting, thanks. I wasn’t aware of Ernestine’s history.

FS Clerkenwell looks nice, especially as it's British. Joanna could be a possibility.

I like the 'feminine yet rigid' aspect of the Ernestine, which is another aspect I was looking for which was to be feminine - not necessarily too feminine though

Rufus has a slight feminine look to it too which is nice

This font looks nice - not sure which it is though - has a feminine appearance to it.

[http://oi46.tinypic.com/567tt.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/oi46.tinypic.com/567tt.jpg "http://oi46.tinypic.com/567tt.jpg") (not sure how to link it on here)

Picture service:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145im_/http:/typophile.com/files/567tt_5862.jpg.png)

That's [Museo Slab](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/www.identifont.com/show?282M) by dutch typedesigner Jos Buivenga.

May I suggest [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/saturday-morning-toast/saturday-...](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/saturday-morning-toast/saturday-morning-toast/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/saturday-morning-toast/saturday-morning-toast/")  
or Cooper Black…

How about [Maple from Process Type Foundry](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/processtypefoundry.com/fonts/maple/)? It would seem to fit the brief, and if being British is a plus its starting point was an 19th-c. English typefounder's design.

Thanks Renko!

Cooper Black looks a bit too retro and Saturday Morning Toast looks too Archaic, thanks though.

Maple is very nice - gives an alternative to the Serif style too.

Is Clarendon too stern (or approaching over-use)?

How about Plume, which is somewhat like Museo Slab?

[http://www.daltonmaag.com/buyonline/fonts/plume](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724084145/http:/www.daltonmaag.com/buyonline/fonts/plume "http://www.daltonmaag.com/buyonline/fonts/plume")

There is also Lexia from Dalton Maag but that might not have the qualities you want.

Tim
